CatDescriptText: Dorothy Kaczmarkski, office worker, 315 Ward Street, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, January 31, 1959, pg. 32 with question: "Do you believe in capital punishment? If so, do you  think that it should be imposed on convicted defendants under the age of 21?" answer reads: "It depends on what the person did.  For instance, the death penalty is justified after a very bad murder.  As for youths under 21 years of age, the death penalty should not be imposed because they don't realize what they have done."
TitMainTitle: Portrait of Dorothy Kaczmarkski wearing light colored scarf, dark button down coat, and leather gloves, holding handbag over left wrist, and folders in arms, standing on sidewalk with pedestrians, building with sign in window that reads "Tasty Sandwiche" on left, and street with car that reads "Smith" on right
